chapter: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: All are live vaccines except:
questions.explanation: attenuated (weakened) pathogens that induce a strong immune response. Rotavirus, Measles, and Varicella vaccines are all live attenuated vaccines. Hepatitis B vaccine contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) and is inactivated. Live vs. Inactivated Vaccines Vaccines can be classified into live attenuated vaccines and inactivated vaccines based on their mechanism of inducing immunity. Live Attenuated Vaccines (LAVs) Contain weakened versions of the pathogen. Provide strong, long-lasting immunity with fewer doses. Not given to immunocompromised individuals due to risk of reactivation. Examples of Live Vaccines: Vaccine Disease Prevented Rotavirus Rotavirus gastroenteritis Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR) Measles, Mumps, Rubella Varicella Chickenpox Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) Poliomyelitis Yellow Fever Yellow Fever BCG Tuberculosis Inactivated Vaccines Contain killed or non-infectious components of the pathogen. Require booster doses for sustained immunity. Safer for immunocompromised patients. Examples of Inactivated Vaccines: Vaccine Disease Prevented Type Hepatitis B Hepatitis B Recombinant subunit Polio (IPV) Poliomyelitis Inactivated Rabies Rabies Inactivated Influenza (Injectable) Influenza Inactivated COVID-19 (Covaxin, Sinopharm) COVID-19 Inactivated Rotavirus (Option A): Incorrect because it is a live oral vaccine used to prevent severe rotavirus diarrhea. Measles (Option C): Incorrect because it is part of the MMR vaccine , which is live attenuated. Varicella (Option D): Incorrect because it is a live attenuated vaccine used to prevent chickenpox . Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition. Pg. 111-112
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Vaccine protocol followed after Disaster?

options.D: Only the health worker given cholera, typhoid, tetanus toxoid

questions.explanation: receive additional protection in disaster situations Cholera, typhoid, and tetanus toxoid vaccinations provided to minimize infection risk Ensures safety while providing medical care Vaccination protocol post- disaster : All vaccines except for measles are contraindicated post-disaster. Multidose vaccines, such as typhoid and cholera vaccines, have poor compliance and have not yet proven to be effective as a large-scale public health measure. The most common post-disaster outbreak is measles. For this reason, measles vaccines can be given within three days of exposure since the time taken for antibodies to form is less than the natural incubation period of the disease. Tetanus vaccine is given based on previous vaccinations and severity of injury. Vaccines for healthcare workers: Cholera, Typhoid, Tetanus, Hep B. Everyone is given diphtheria (Option A) : Diphtheria vaccination likely already part of routine immunization schedules Everyone is given tetanus toxoid (Option B) : Tetanus toxoid crucial in disaster scenarios, especially for those with injuries Everyone is given cholera vaccine (Option C) : Cholera vaccination not typically administered to everyone in general disaster response Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 111
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the options listed below indicates the degree of heat resistance exhibited by vaccines?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) VVM Explanation: The Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) is used to indicate the degree of heat resistance and the extent to which a vaccine has been exposed to heat. It is a color-changing indicator attached to vaccine vials to help assess whether a vaccine has been stored or transported at the correct temperature. This helps in determining if a vaccine remains safe and effective for use. VMV (Option A) : There is no known vaccine-related term called VMV. MVV (Option C) : This is not a recognized term related to vaccine heat resistance. VMM (Option D) : This also is not related to heat resistance in vaccines. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 24, Page 118
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: There is an outbreak of acute encephalitis in the community and a vaccination drive is launched. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Killed and intramuscular. Explanation: Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is the most common cause of viral encephalitis outbreaks in endemic regions. The Japanese Encephalitis vaccine (JE vaccine) is available in two types: inactivated (killed) and live attenuated. The inactivated (killed) vaccine is commonly given intramuscularly (IM) as part of mass vaccination programs in outbreak settings. Live attenuated vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are administered subcutaneously (SC), but they are generally used for routine immunization rather than in acute outbreak settings. Types of Japanese Encephalitis Vaccines Vaccine Type Examples Route of Administration Usage Inactivated (Killed) JEEV, IXIARO Intramuscular (IM) Used in outbreaks & travelers Live Attenuated SA 14-14-2 Subcutaneous (SC) Routine immunization Live and subcutaneous (Option B) : Incorrect. Although there is a live attenuated JE vaccine (e.g., SA 14-14-2 ), it is usually administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly. However, this option does not align with standard killed vaccines used in most vaccination drives. Live and intramuscular (Option C) : Incorrect. Live attenuated vaccines for JE are administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly. Killed and subcutaneous (Option D) : Incorrect. Killed vaccines are administered intramuscularly, not subcutaneously. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 332, 333
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Considering the immune status of a girl child who has been experiencing repeated yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since the age of 3 months, which vaccine should be avoided?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Measles/MMR Explanation: Measles/MMR should be avoided due to the live virus components, which can be risky for immunocompromised children. A child who has a history of repeated yeast infections and respiratory viral infections may have an underlying immune deficiency or immunodeficiency disorder . Immunocompromised children, particularly those with T-cell deficiency (such as in conditions like DiGeorge syndrome or severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) ), should avoid live vaccines due to the risk of severe infection. The Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine contains live attenuated viruses for measles, mumps, and rubella. In immunocompromised children, live vaccines pose a risk of causing active infections or serious complications due to their weakened immune system. National Immunization Schedule (India) Vaccine Age Route Site Type of Vaccine BCG At birth (up to 1 year) Intradermal Left upper arm Live attenuated Hepatitis B (Birth Dose) At birth (within 24 hrs) Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Inactivated OPV (Zero Dose) At birth (within 15 days) Oral - Live attenuated Pentavalent (DPT + Hib + Hep B) 6, 10, 14 weeks Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh DPT (toxoid), Hib & Hep B (inactivated) OPV 6, 10, 14 weeks Oral - Live attenuated Rotavirus 6, 10, 14 weeks Oral - Live attenuated IPV (Fractional) 6 & 14 weeks Intradermal Right upper arm Inactivated PCV (Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine) 6, 14 weeks, and 9 months Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Conjugate Measles & Rubella (MR) 9-12 months & 16-24 months Subcutaneous Right upper arm Live attenuated JE (Japanese Encephalitis) 9-12 months & 16-24 months Subcutaneous Left upper arm Live attenuated DPT Booster-1 16-24 months Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Toxoid OPV Booster 16-24 months Oral - Live attenuated PCV Booster 9-12 months Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Conjugate Measles/MR Booster 16-24 months Subcutaneous Right upper arm Live attenuated DPT Booster-2 5-6 years Intramuscular Deltoid Toxoid TT (Tetanus Toxoid) 10 years & 16 years Intramuscular Deltoid Toxoid Cervical Cancer (HPV) 9-14 years (girls) Intramuscular Deltoid Recombinant Killed IPV (Option A) : The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains inactivated (killed) virus, which is safe for immunocompromised children because it cannot cause infection. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus) (Option C) : The DPT vaccine is an inactivated vaccine and is safe for immunocompromised children. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid) (Option D) : This is a toxoid vaccine and is also safe for immunocompromised children, as it does not contain live bacteria. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 112, 162 https://www.pmc.gov.in/en/NIS-for-Infants-Children-and-Pregnant-Women https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/41016395871489662752.pdf
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program for a 10- year-old student in school?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) TT/ Td Explanation: According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India, children at the age of 10 years receive the Td vaccine (Tetanus and Diphtheria, previously TT). This booster dose maintains immunity provided by earlier doses given during infancy and early childhood. Vaccine Age Route Site Type of Vaccine BCG (Option A ruled out) At birth (up to 1 year) Intradermal Left upper arm Live attenuated Hepatitis B (Birth Dose) At birth (within 24 hrs) Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Inactivated OPV (Zero Dose) At birth (within 15 days) Oral - Live attenuated Pentavalent (DPT + Hib + Hep B) 6, 10, 14 weeks Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh DPT (toxoid), Hib & Hep B (inactivated) OPV 6, 10, 14 weeks Oral - Live attenuated Rotavirus 6, 10, 14 weeks Oral - Live attenuated IPV (Fractional) 6 & 14 weeks Intradermal Right upper arm Inactivated PCV (Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine) 6, 14 weeks, and 9 months Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Conjugate Measles & Rubella (MR) (Option B ruled out) 9-12 months & 16-24 months Subcutaneous Right upper arm Live attenuated JE (Japanese Encephalitis) 9-12 months & 16-24 months Subcutaneous Left upper arm Live attenuated DPT Booster-1 16-24 months Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Toxoid OPV Booster 16-24 months Oral - Live attenuated PCV Booster 9-12 months Intramuscular Anterolateral thigh Conjugate Measles/MR Booster 16-24 months Subcutaneous Right upper arm Live attenuated DPT Booster-2 5-6 years Intramuscular Deltoid Toxoid TT (Tetanus Toxoid) 10 years & 16 years Intramuscular Deltoid Toxoid Cervical Cancer (HPV) 9-14 years (girls) Intramuscular Deltoid Recombinant National Immunization Schedule (India) DPT (Option D): Used for children below 7 years. Beyond this age, the Td vaccine replaces DPT to minimize side effects from higher diphtheria toxoid content. Reference: https://www.pmc.gov.in/en/NIS-for-Infants-Children-and-Pregnant-Women https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/41016395871489662752.pdf
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In the market, there are several new vaccines being researched, and their effectiveness is being evaluated and displayed in the image provided. Which of the recently developed vaccines demonstrate comparable efficacy to the previous vaccine?
questions.explanation: Conclusion based on forest plot, comparing efficacies. Confidence intervals overlap, indicating similar efficacy. D only (Option A): Only includes plot D, neglecting C and E. D and E (Option B): Only includes plots D and E, neglecting C. A, B, C and D (Option D): Includes plots A and B, which differ significantly from efficacy zone, unlike C, D, and E. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 116
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which vaccine among the options exhibits a seroconversion rate that is quicker than the incubation period of the corresponding disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Measles: Amongst the above options, measles vaccine has a faster seroconversion rate as compared to the incubation period of the disease and this is why measles vaccine is given when a disaster or an epidemic occurs. Seroconversion: is the transition from the point of viral infection to when antibodies of the virus become present in the blood. Seroconversion rates are one of the methods used for determining the efficacy of a vaccine. The higher the rate of seroconversion, the more protective the vaccine for a greater proportion of the population. Seroconversion does not inherently confer immunity or resistance to infection. Only some antibodies, such as anti-spike antibodies for COVID-19, confer protection. Coronavirus (Option A): The coronavirus vaccine has almost the same seroconversion rate as compared to the incubation period of the disease. Polio (Option C): The seroconversion rate of the polio vaccine is slower than its incubation period. Mumps (Option D): The mumps vaccine has a slower seroconversion rate than its incubation period. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7519951/
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is the initial step when an immunization survey is being conducted?

options.C: Completing the cluster and summary forms
options.D: Calculating the total fertility rate of the area

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Cluster identification The initial step in conducting an immunization survey is Cluster identification. The major steps of an immunization survey are as follows: Planning the survey by finding the clusters and deciding how many interviewers are required. To conduct the survey in which the interviewers visit houses and get information on the immunization status of the clusters (Option B) To tabulate the data by completing the cluster and the summary forms (Option C) To analyse the data which helps in evaluating the immunization status and the reasons for the failure of immunization. To take action on the reports made by evaluating the data. Calculating the total fertility rate of the area (Option D): This is not typically part of an immunization survey; it is more relevant to demographic studies. Reference: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/69087/WHO_IVB_04.23.pdf;jsessionid=D82166D63138138 5A04DE4AE37EF648E?sequence=1
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of these vaccines do not follow open vial policy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Measles Measles vaccine do not follow open vial policy Open vial policy States that “vaccine vials, once opened, can be reused in subsequent sessions for up to 28 days, provided that they are maintained in appropriate cold chain conditions to reduce the wastage of vaccines. All liquid vaccines follow open-vial policies. Eg : Hepatitis B , DPT, Pentavalent, OPV, IPV, PCV, Td. Reconstituted vaccines such as MMR, BCG, JE, Yellow fever vaccine along with Rotavirus vaccine do not follow open vial policy Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th edition page 120
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A child presents with a dog bite from a street dog. On examination, an abrasion of 1.5 cm is present, with slight oozing. Which of the following statements is correct? 1. Category 3 wound 2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes 3. Clean the wound with spirit 4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing 5. Equine immunoglobulin is given a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice 6. The intradermal vaccine is administered on day 0,3,7,28
questions.explanation: exposure as per WHO guidelines. This category includes single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membranes with saliva, and exposure to broken skin. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes (2) : Immediate and thorough washing of the wound with soap and water for 15–20 minutes is a key step in rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). It significantly reduces the viral load at the site. Clean the wound with spirit (3) : This is correct . After washing and drying the wound, disinfectants like povidone-iodine and spirit can be applied. Loose suturing of the wound with proper dressing (4) : Suturing is avoided in rabies-prone wounds unless absolutely necessary. If required, it is done only after administering rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound. Equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice (5) : ERIG is administered in Category 3 wounds at a dose of 40 IU/kg body weight. It is infiltrated locally around the wound as much as anatomically possible, with the remaining dose given intramuscularly, only once . Intradermal vaccine schedule: Days 0, 3, 7, 28 (6) : The child should receive the intradermal rabies vaccine on this schedule as part of PEP for a Category 3 wound. Explanation for Incorrect Options: Option A (2, 3, 5, 6) : Cleaning the wound with spirit (3) is incorrect. Option C (1, 2, 3, 5) : Cleaning with spirit (3) is incorrect, and the vaccine schedule is missing (6). Option D (1, 2, 3, 6) : Cleaning with spirit (3) is incorrect, and RIG (5) is omitted. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5790559/ Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 324-327
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following regarding the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is true? 1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare. 2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat. 3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine 4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM. 5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is an acceptable range. 6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.explanation: healthcare workers in primary healthcare. This is true. VVM is a tool used in primary healthcare to monitor the exposure of vaccines to heat during transportation and storage. It is particularly useful in areas with unreliable cold chain systems. 2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat. This is also true. The VVM works by showing the cumulative amount of heat the vaccine has been exposed to, indicating whether the vaccine has been subjected to conditions that might reduce its efficacy. 3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine. This is false. The VVM does not directly assess the efficacy of the vaccine. It only shows whether the vaccine has been exposed to heat beyond its acceptable limit, which might affect its effectiveness. 4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM. This is false. The VVM does not calculate the expiry date of the vaccine. It is used to monitor heat exposure, not to predict or calculate the expiry date. 5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range. This is false. The VVM cannot be used to relax the expiry date of a vaccine. If the vaccine has been exposed to temperatures beyond the recommended limit, its efficacy may be compromised regardless of its expiration date. 6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used. This is false. When the square and circle on the VVM are the same color, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to heat for too long and should not be used, as it may have lost its potency. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page 121, 122
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding rabies immunoglobulin?

options.A: It is exclusively given only in the deltoid
options.D: If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.explanation: administered by infiltrating as much of the dose as possible around and into the wound site, with the remaining dose injected intramuscularly (usually in the gluteal region). It should not be given in the deltoid or gluteal region alone without infiltrating the wound. The dose is 20 IU/kg (Option B) is true for human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG). For equine RIG (ERIG), the dose is 40 IU/kg. Administer it immediately after exposure (Option C) is true . RIG should be given as soon as possible after exposure, especially in Category III wounds, to neutralise the virus at the site of entry. If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred (Option D) is true . ERIG is used when HRIG is unavailable, and it is equally effective when administered correctly. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 324-327
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What would be the most appropriate approach to managing a young male patient who has presented at the hospital with a clean-cut wound that is not bleeding, and who received a complete tetanus vaccination 10 years ago?

options.A: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Single-dose tetanus toxoid Explanation: Single-dose tetanus toxoid needed for clean cut wound with previous booster within 10 years Thorough wound cleaning advised, removal of foreign bodies Tetanus Management Protocol: Category Clean wound Unclean wound Category A Has had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose (full immunisation) within the past 5 years. Only wound care. Only wound care. Category B Full immunization > 5 years ago < 10 years. Wound Care + TT single dose. Wound Care + TT single dose. Category C Full Immunization > 10 years ago. Wound Care + TT single dose. Wound Care + TT single dose + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin. Category D Unknown, not known, never taken immunisation. Wound Care + TT complete course. Wound Care + TT complete course + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 361
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines is not recommended after 65 years?
questions.explanation: as older individuals are less likely to benefit. Influenza, Pneumococcal, and Herpes Zoster vaccines are strongly recommended for adults ≥ 65 years to prevent severe infections. HPV vaccination is primarily for younger individuals to prevent cervical and other HPV-related cancers. Older adults have likely been exposed to HPV already , reducing vaccine efficacy. Adult Vaccination Recommendations ( ≥ 65 Years) Aging individuals face an increased risk of respiratory infections, viral reactivation, and opportunistic infections due to immune decline. Vaccination is a critical preventive strategy. Recommended Vaccines for Adults ≥ 65 Years Vaccine Purpose Recommended After 65? Influenza Prevents seasonal flu complications Yes, annually Pneumococcal (PCV15/PCV20, PPSV23) Prevents pneumonia, bacteremia, meningitis Yes, once or as per schedule Herpes Zoster (Recombinant Zoster Vaccine - RZV) Prevents shingles and postherpetic neuralgia Yes, 2 doses after 50 years Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis (Tdap/Td) Prevents tetanus and pertussis Yes, booster every 10 years COVID-19 Reduces risk of severe COVID-19 Yes, as per updated recommendations HPV Prevents cervical and other cancers Not recommended after 45 years Why is the HPV Vaccine Not Given After 65? Most individuals are already exposed to HPV by this age. Vaccine efficacy is highest in younger populations (9-26 years). No added benefit in older adults, as HPV-related cancer risk decreases. Influenza (Option A): Incorrect because annual flu vaccination is recommended to prevent severe complications. Herpes Zoster (Option B): Incorrect because shingles risk increases with age, so vaccination is advised after 50 years . Pneumococcal (Option C): Incorrect because pneumococcal vaccine is recommended after 65 years to prevent pneumonia and invasive infections . Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4928529/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4928530/
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is the schedule of the OPV vaccine?
questions.explanation: 14 weeks along with DPT and other vaccines. Additionally, a booster dose is given at 16–24 months. Differences between IPV and OPV: Characteristic IPV (salk type) OPV (sabin type) Type of vaccine Killed formalised virus Live attenuated virus Mode of administration S/C or IM (0.5 mL) Oral (2 drops) Type of immunity Only humoral Humoral and intestinal Prevention of Paralysis Paralysis + Intestinal re-infection Control of epidemics Not useful Effective Storage & transport Less stringent conditions Requires sub-zero temperatures Shelf life Longer Short VAPP (Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio) Zero incidences 1 per 1 million vaccines Schedule of OPV: 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years; 2 oral drops Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm. fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose. From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm). Reference: Park, 27th Edition, Page 240
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is the fIPV dose schedule under the National Immunization Schedule?

options.B: At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years

questions.explanation: part of the routine immunisation schedule. Additionally, a booster dose is given at 9 months. Differences between IPV and OPV: Characteristic IPV (salk type) OPV (sabin type) Type of vaccine Killed formalised virus Live attenuated virus Mode of administration S/C or IM (0.5 mL) Oral (2 drops) Type of immunity Only humoral Humoral and intestinal Prevention of Paralysis Paralysis + Intestinal re-infection Control of epidemics Not useful Effective Storage & transport Less stringent conditions Requires sub-zero temperatures Shelf life Longer Short VAPP (Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio) Zero incidences 1 per 1 million vaccines Schedule of OPV: 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years; 2 oral drops Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm. fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose. From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm). 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks (Option A) is incorrect because fIPV is given at 6 and 14 weeks , not at 10 weeks. At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years (Option B) is incorrect because this schedule includes OPV doses and does not match the fIPV schedule, which is 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and a booster at 9 months . 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 12 weeks (Option D) is incorrect because fIPV is not given at 10 and 12 weeks. The correct schedule is 6 weeks and 14 weeks , with a booster at 9 months . Reference: Park, 27th Edition, Page 240
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following vaccine is kept at lowest level?
questions.explanation: Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs) compared to the other vaccines listed. Incorrect Options: Option B - DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): DPT is a combination vaccine and is sensitive to temperature changes. It needs to be stored in a controlled environment to maintain its efficacy, typically at a temperature range of 2°C to 8°C in ILRs. Option C - Hep B (Hepatitis B Vaccine): Hepatitis B vaccine is sensitive to temperature and must be kept at a stable temperature of 2°C to 8°C, similar to DPT, but it is more sensitive to freezing. Thus, it requires careful monitoring to avoid freezing. Option D - Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Shanchol vaccine consists of?
questions.explanation: Vibrio cholerae and requires two doses for complete immunization. The Shanchol vaccine is a bivalent vaccine, meaning it covers two different strains of Vibrio cholerae (O1 and O139) and typically requires two doses for full protection. Incorrect Options: Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: When are the three doses of fIPV ideally given as per the National Immunization Schedule?

options.A: 3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months
options.B: At 10 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months
options.C: At 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 18 completed months
options.D: 3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 18 completed months

questions.explanation: Inactivated Polio vaccine) is administered by intramuscular or fractional dose by intradermal injection Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm. fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose. From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm). Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 240
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 10 year old child is brought to the clinic for his regular immunization. What vaccine is given as a part of the national immunization schedule?
questions.explanation: as a part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old school child. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine: The TT/Td vaccine is given to provide protection against tetanus and diphtheria. It is often administered as a booster dose every 10 years to maintain immunity. At the age of 10, a child may receive a TT/Td vaccine as a part of their routine immunization schedule. National Immunization Schedule: Time Vaccines At birth BCG, OPV0 (OPV birth dose), Hep B (birth dose) 6 weeks OPV1, Penta1, RVV1, fIPV1, PCV1 10 weeks OPV2, Penta2, RVV2 14 weeks OPV3, Penta3, RVV3, fIPV2, PCV2 9 completed months MR1, JE1, PCV booster, fIPV3, vitamin A 16-24 months MR2, JE2, OPV booster, DPT booster 1 5-6 years DPT booster 2 10 years Td 16 years Td Incorrect Options: BCG (Option B): The BCG vaccine is typically given at birth or during infancy to protect against tuberculosis. It is not part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old child. MMR (Option C): The MMR vaccine is usually administered around 12-15 months of age and a second dose at 4-6 years of age. It protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. By the age of 10, most children would have already received the recommended doses of the MMR vaccine. DTP (Option D): The DPT vaccine is typically given during infancy and early childhood to protect against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough), and tetanus. By the age of 10, children would have already completed the recommended doses of the DPT vaccine series. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no:136 https://main.mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/245453521061489663873.pdf https://nhm.gov.in/New_Updates_2018/N HM_Components/Immunization/report/National_%20Immunization_Schedule.pdf
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide vaccine?
questions.explanation: vaccine. It contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) produced through recombinant DNA technology. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D: They are examples of polysaccharide vaccines. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the rotavirus vaccine is incorrect?

options.B: Cannot be given after 6 months of age
options.D: It has monovalent and pentavalent form

questions.explanation: rotavirus vaccine is typically given in multiple doses, starting at around 2 months of age. The series is usually completed by 8 months of age. While the first dose should not be given after 15 weeks of age, the series can and should be completed by 8 months. The recommendation is to complete the vaccination series by 8 months of age. Incorrect Options: Correct Option A - Given orally : True : The rotavirus vaccine is administered orally. It is designed to immunize the gastrointestinal tract directly, which is the site of rotavirus infection. Option C - Live vaccine: True : The rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine. It contains a weakened form of the virus that stimulates the immune system without causing disease in healthy individuals. Option D - It has monovalent and pentavalent form: True : There are two types of rotavirus vaccines available: the monovalent vaccine (Rotarix) and the pentavalent vaccine (RotaTeq). Rotarix contains one strain of the rotavirus, while RotaTeq contains five different strains. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 10-week-old baby has come for vaccination. The baby has had a previous history of inconsolable crying and fever (40 degrees C) after vaccination at 6 weeks. What should be the next step now?
questions.explanation: vaccine Contraindications to pertussis vaccine: anaphylaxis, encephalopathy, family history of CNS disorders, concurrent febrile illness Baby's symptoms are likely vaccine-related, no contraindications present Proceeding with DPT vaccination recommended Reference: DTP in progressive neurological disorder Egg allergy- Yellow fever vaccine Vaccines in HIV patients - adults, children . Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th edition Pg 111, 178
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the schedule and route of administration of MR vaccine and vitamin A?

options.A: MR vaccine administered subcutaneously along with oral vitamin A at 8 months
options.B: MR vaccine administered intramuscularly along oral vitamin A at 8 months
options.C: MR vaccine administered subcutaneously along with oral vitamin A at 9 months
options.D: MR vaccine administered intramuscularly along with oral vitamin A at 9 months

questions.explanation: months Explanation: National Immunization Schedule: Time Vaccines At birth BCG, OPV0 (OPV birth dose), Hep B (birth dose) 6 weeks OPV1, Penta1, RVV1, fIPV1, PCV1 10 weeks OPV2, Penta2, RVV2 14 weeks OPV3, Penta3, RVV3, fIPV2, PCV2 9 completed months MR1, JE1, PCV booster, fIPV3, vitamin A 16-24 months MR2, JE2, OPV booster, DPT booster 1 5-6 years DPT booster 2 10 years Td 16 years Td Age Vitamin A Dosage(Oral route) <6 months 50,000 IU 6 - 12 months 100,000 IU 9 months 100,000 IU 1-5 years (every 6 months) 200,000 IU Route Vaccine Dose Site Oral OPV 2 drops Oral Rotavirus 5 drops Oral Intradermal BCG 0.1 ml (0.05 ml until 1 month) Left upper arm fIPV 0.1 ml Right upper arm Intramuscular Pentavalent (DPT, Hep B, Hib ) 0.5 ml Antero-lateral side of mid-thigh PCV 0.5 ml Antero-lateral side of mid-thigh Td 0.5 ml Upper arm Subcutaneous MR 0.5 ml Right upper arm JE 0.5 ml Left upper arm Live vaccine via S.C Killed vaccine via I.M Intranasal Influenza 0.2 mL (0.1 mL each nostril) Nasopharynx Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27 edition, pg no 115, 136, 459 https://main.mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/245453521061489663873.pdf https://nhm.gov.in/New_Updates_2018/N HM_Components/Immunization/report/National_%20Immunization_Schedule.pdf
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Td vaccine Explanation: TT/Td vaccine given at 10 years in school program Pentavalent vaccine given at 6, 10, 14 weeks with boosters TT boosters at 10, 16 years Prevents Tetanus from Clostridium tetani Tetanospasmin is dangerous exotoxin Soil is source Herd immunity ineffective National Immunization Schedule: Vaccine Due age Dose Route Site BCG At birth < 1 month - 0.05 ml > 1 month - 0.1 ml Intradermal Left upper arm Hepatitis B (Option D) At birth 0.5 ml Intramuscular Anterolateral aspect of left mid thigh OPV -0 At birth 2 drops Oral Oral OPV 1,2,3 6, 10,14 weeks 2 drops Oral Oral Pentavalent 1,2,3 6,10,14 weeks 0.5 ml Intramuscular Anterolateral aspect of left mid thigh IPV 6,14 weeks 0.1 ml Intradermal Right upper arm Rotavirus (Option B) 6,10,14 weeks 5 drops Oral Oral Pneumococcal vaccine 6,14 weeks At 9 completed months 0.5 ml Intramuscular Anterolateral aspect of right mid thigh 1st dose Measles/ Rubella (Option A) At 9 completed months - 12 months 0.5 ml Subcutaneous Right upper arm 1st dose JE At 9 completed months - 12 months 0.5 ml Subcutaneous Left upper arm 1st dose Vitamin A At 9 completed months 1 ml Oral Oral DPT- booster 1 16-24 months 0.5 ml Intramuscular Anterolateral aspect of left mid thigh 2nd dose Measles/ Rubella (Option A) 16-24 months 0.5 ml Subcutaneous Right upper arm OPV booster 16-24 months 2 drops Oral Oral 2nd dose JE 16-24 months 0.5 ml Subcutaneous Left upper arm 2nd-9th dose Vit A At 16, then one dose every 6 months 2 ml Oral Oral DPT- booster 2 5-6 years 0.5 ml Intramuscular Upper arm TT 10 years and 16 years 0.5 ml Intramuscular Upper arm For Pregnant women TT-1 Early pregnancy 0.5 ml Intramuscular Upper arm TT-2 4 weeks following TT1 0.5 ml Intramuscular Upper arm TT booster If mother has taken TT disease in pregnancy within the last 3 years 0.5 ml Intramuscular Upper arm Reference: Park textbook of preventive and social medicine, 25th edition, Pg. no. 135.
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which test is employed to assess freeze-induced damage in vaccines?
questions.explanation: the vaccine vial to observe clumping or visible particles Indicates potential damage due to freezing Incorrect Options: Option B - Schick test: Determines immunity to diphtheria Option C - Habel test: No commonly known test in vaccine context Option D - Tine test: Determines immune response to tuberculin antigen for TB diagnosis Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is a heat-sensitive indicator of vaccine viability?
questions.explanation: packages Provides visual indication of excessive heat exposure Helps determine vaccine viability and safety Incorrect Options: Option A - e-VIN: Real-time monitoring system for vaccine stocks and temperatures, not heat-sensitive indicator Option B - Freeze indicator : Indicates exposure to freezing temperatures, not vaccine viability or heat exposure Option D - Fridge indicator : Monitors refrigerator temperature for vaccine storage, not specifically a heat-sensitive indicator Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: BCG vaccine provides protection against which of the following?
questions.explanation: Nervous System) TB and disseminated TB. It primarily prevents severe forms of TB in infants and young children. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pulmonary TB. Option C - Pulmonary and CNS TB. Option D - Pulmonary and skeletal T. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: As per the national immunization schedule, which vaccines are indicated at the first visit for immunization of a 13-month-old baby who has not been previously immunized?

options.A: BCG, OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Rota virus 1st dose
options.B: OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Measles 1st dose
options.D: OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose

questions.explanation: polio, administered at this visit DPT 1st dose: Protects against diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus, usually given at this visit Measles 1st dose: Provides immunity against measles, typically given at 9-12 months but can be given at 13-month visit if missed Incorrect Options: Option A - BCG, OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Rotavirus 1st dose: BCG can't be given after 1 year Option B - OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Measles 1st dose: Pentavalent can't be given after 1 year Option C - BCG, OPV 1st dose, Measles 1st dose: BCG can't be given after 1 year Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae has 23 serotypes. In which of the following patients is this vaccine most beneficial ?

options.B: A patient with sickle cell disease
options.D: A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.explanation: issues. Recommended to prevent pneumococcal infections with the 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine. Incorrect Options: Option A - A child < 2 years: Children under 2 already receive routine pneumococcal vaccination. Option C - A patient with cystic fibrosis: Polysaccharide vaccine may not be optimal for immunocompromised patients like those with cystic fibrosis. Option D - Option D: A patient with recurrent otitis media: Polysaccharide vaccine may not target specific serotypes causing otitis media. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What would be the appropriate treatment for a 5-year-old boy who had received a complete course of rabies vaccine in December 2018, but was bitten on the toe by his fully vaccinated pet dog in November 2019, resulting in bleeding at the bite site?
questions.explanation: vaccination, lowering the risk of transmission. Administering 2 doses of rabies vaccine on Day 0 and Day 3 provides additional protection and covers potential immunity gaps. Incorrect Options: Option A - No treatment: No treatment may leave gaps in protection despite previous vaccinations. Option C - 5 doses of vaccine with Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulin is unnecessary as the dog is fully vaccinated. Option D - 5 doses of vaccine: 5 doses are excessive given the circumstances. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: At a PHC, vaccine storage is done in?
questions.explanation: medications. They maintain stable temperature ranges required for vaccine storage. Incorrect Options: Option A - Vaccine carrier: Used for transporting vaccines, not long-term storage. Option C - Walk-in Cold rooms: Large refrigerated spaces, not typically found at PHCs. Option D - Ice packs: Provide temporary cooling during transportation, not long-term storage. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines ?
questions.explanation: contain weakened forms of infectious agents Stimulate immune system without causing full-blown illness Interval ensures adequate immune response, minimizes interference Incorrect Options: Option A - 2 weeks: Shorter interval may not allow sufficient time for immune response Option C - 8 weeks: Longer interval may not be necessary, recommended minimum is shorter Option D - 12 weeks: Even longer interval generally not required for most live vaccines Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which vaccine among the options provided is not recommended during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: attenuated virus, theoretical risk to developing fetus Not recommended for pregnant women Administered before pregnancy or after delivery if woman is not immune to chickenpox Incorrect Options: Option A - Hepatitis A vaccine: Hepatitis A vaccine safe during pregnancy, recommended for at-risk women Option B - Hepatitis B vaccine: Hepatitis B vaccine safe during pregnancy, recommended for all pregnant women Option C - Rabies vaccine: Rabies vaccine not contraindicated during pregnancy, benefits may outweigh risks in certain situations Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 4-year-old male child developed with sore throat, difficulty in swallowing, and mild fever . On examination, the clinical picture shown below is seen. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition?

options.A: It is administered on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
options.B: A history of anaphylaxis with same vaccine is not a contraindication
options.C: The cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
options.D: The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.explanation: statement, history of anaphylaxis is a contraindication Incorrect Options: Option A - It is administered on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh: Administered on anterolateral aspect of thigh, correct site for vaccine administration Option C - The cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7 years of age: Cellular pertussis component not recommended after 7 years of age, true statement Option D - The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: Diphtheria toxoid dose in adults may be lower than pediatric dose, true statement
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In the laboratory, a microbiologist is preparing the BCG vaccine. Which of the following substances is used as a diluent for the BCG vaccine?
questions.explanation: sodium chloride in water with the same concentration as body fluids Ensures proper mixing of the vaccine powder or freeze-dried formulation Incorrect Options: Option B - Distilled water: Less commonly used for vaccine dilution Option C - Dextrose: Not typically used for BCG vaccine dilution Option D - Colloids: Not commonly used as diluents for vaccines Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: BCG is diluted with:
questions.explanation: sodium chloride solution) before administration. Incorrect Options: Option B - Distilled water: Lacks necessary electrolytes for vaccine viability. Option C - Ringer lactate: Not standard for BCG vaccine reconstitution. Option D - Distilled water (mentioned twice in the options): Insufficient for maintaining vaccine viability. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: How long is the protection provided by the Yellow fever vaccine considered valid for?
questions.explanation: Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In which of the following outbreaks is mass vaccination considered to be the most effective?
questions.explanation: vaccination and with high vaccine coverage achievable. Polio is highly infectious, especially in children, but can be prevented through vaccination. Mass vaccination campaigns for polio aim for high vaccine coverage to interrupt transmission and protect susceptible individuals. Incorrect Options: Option A - Cholera: Controlled through other measures like water and sanitation improvements. Option B - Typhoid: Usually targeted at high-risk groups, not mass campaigns. Option D - Whooping cough: prevented by vaccination but not typically through mass campaigns. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines are given at birth?
questions.explanation: many countries BCG: Tuberculosis protection OPV: Polio protection Hepatitis B vaccine: Protects against Hepatitis B Administered within 24 hours of birth Incorrect Options: Option A - Pentavalent, MR, HiB: Pentavalent, MR, and HiB not given at birth Option B - BCG, OPV, MR: MR vaccine given at 9 months, not at birth Option D - BCG, IP, Hepatitis B: IP vaccine usually given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, not at birth Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: At what age is the first dose of hepatitis B vaccine given?
questions.explanation: Provides timely protection against transmission from mother to baby Subsequent doses: At 1-2 months and 6 months of age to complete the series Recommended as routine childhood vaccination by WHO and CDC Incorrect Options: Option B - 6 weeks: Safe to administer at 6 weeks but recommended to complete series as soon as possible Option C - 10 weeks: 10 weeks would be too long a delay Option D - 6 months: Vaccine is safe and effective after 6 months, but recommended to administer as early as possible, ideally within 24 hours of birth Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In how many days should the post exposure Measles vaccine be given?
questions.explanation: 14th day -rashes start IP of vaccine-induced measles is 7 days. Post-exposure vaccine must be used with in 3 days of exposure Incorrect Options: Option A, C and D Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Vaccines And Cold Chain-Previous Year Questions
